an3.72:1.1: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
an3.72:1.2: Then a householder who was a disciple of the Ājīvaka ascetics went up to Venerable Ānanda, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:
an3.72:2.2: Who in the world is practicing well?
an3.72:2.3: Who in the world has done well?”
an3.72:2.4: “Well then, householder, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
an3.72:2.6: Is the teaching of those who teach for giving up greed, hate, and delusion well explained or not?
an3.72:2.7: Or how do you see this?”
an3.72:2.8: “The teaching of those who teach for giving up greed, hate, and delusion is well explained.
an3.72:3.2: Are those who practice for giving up greed, hate, and delusion practicing well or not?
an3.72:3.3: Or how do you see this?”
an3.72:3.4: “Those who practice for giving up greed, hate, and delusion are practicing well.
an3.72:4.2: Have those who’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion—so they’re cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future—done well in the world, or not?
an3.72:4.3: Or how do you see this?”
an3.72:4.4: “Those who’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion have done well in the world.
an3.72:5.2: ‘The teaching of those who teach for giving up greed, hate, and delusion is well explained.’
an3.72:5.4: ‘Those who practice for giving up greed, hate, and delusion are practicing well.’
an3.72:5.6: ‘Those who’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion have done well in the world.’”
an3.72:6.2: There’s no acclaiming your own teaching or disrespecting someone else’s,
an3.72:6.3: just teaching what’s relevant in that context. The goal is spoken of, but the self is not involved.
an3.72:6.4: You, sir, teach Dhamma for giving up greed, hate, and delusion.
an3.72:6.6: You, sir, practice for giving up greed, hate, and delusion.
an3.72:6.7: You in the world are practicing well.
an3.72:6.8: You’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion.
an3.72:6.9: You in the world have done well.
an3.72:7.2: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Venerable Ānanda has made the teaching clear in many ways.
an3.72:7.3: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
an3.72:7.4: From this day forth, may Venerable Ānanda remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
